0 Entry from Ukraine and residency in Germany
1 The Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs helps people who have fled to Germany because of war with issues relating to employment and social security.
2 During the 90 days in which you can stay in Germany legally without a visa, you can decide whether you would like to stay in Germany longer.
3 If you decide to stay longer, you have the following options:
4 What happens after I enter the country?
5 Where can I register in Germany and where do I get accommodation and food?
6 The procedure is divided into four successive steps:
7 First registration and (in the case of benefit recipients) distribution to a place of residence, as well as registration of the residential address at the destination and application for a residence title.
8 You can find further information here.
9 Can I work in Germany with a residence permit for temporary protection?
10 Yes, you can.
11 However, gainful employment must first be permitted by the foreigners authority.
12 When the residence permit is issued, the foreigners authority will already enter in the residence title that gainful employment is permitted, even if no concrete job is in prospect yet.
13 This means that no further work permit from another authority is required.
14 Persons with a residence permit for temporary protection in Germany are also eligible for advice and placement services in accordance with Social Code III (SGB III) through the employment agencies.
15 Should Ukrainian nationals have to apply for asylum?
16 No, that is not necessary.
17 The required protection will be granted in another, faster procedure.
18 Ukrainian nationals are therefore advised not to apply for asylum.
19 However, the right to apply for asylum at a later stage continues regardless.
20 Registration upon entry does not constitute an asylum application.
21 The implementation of an asylum procedure requires an application for asylum to be filed at the competent branch office of the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees.
22 For these reasons, filing an asylum application is not required to secure a right of residence or to claim social benefits.
23 The Federal Ministry of the Interior and Home Affairs offers a digital information service in German, English, Russian, and Ukrainian.

context:
0 Irregular and illegal employment
1 A job that is paid but not registered with the Finanzamt (tax office) and health insurance company, and for which thus no taxes and social security payments are paid, is illegal and is referred to in Germany as "Schwarzarbeit” or “moonlighting” in English.
2 It can be punished with fines and prison!
3 If someone gets social benefits or unemployment benefits, but still works and keeps their job secret from the Sozialamt (Social Welfare Office), the Arbeitsagentur (Employment Agency) or the Jobcenter, this is also illegal employment:
4 A person is thus wrongly receiving state benefits, even though they are in paid employment.
5 This is forbidden and against the law.
6 In German it is known as “Schwarzarbeit”.
7 You should always inform the office where you get benefits if you want to start a job;
8 you are allowed to earn money while still receiving social benefits (the benefits are then recalculated) but you must inform the case officers of every kind of earnings and income immediately.
9 Taking up work even though you are forbidden to work is also regarded as illegal employment.
10 Depending on your country of origin and reason for staying, illegal employment can lead to you being permanently forbidden to work!

0 Spousal residency – independent right of residence
1 The rules for foreign spouses or life partners who move here can vary.
2 The decisive factor is whether or not the partner living in Germany possesses German nationality.
3 If you move to Munich, you must register as soon as possible (the government stipulates a deadline of 14 days) in the Bürgerbüro (Residents’ Office).
4 There you will receive a registration certificate.
5 In order to register, you can attend the Bürgerbüro (Residents’ Office) in person, or have a person authorised by you to submit the completed and signed registration form.
6 You require an appointment to attend the Bürgerbüro.
7 You are issued the national visa (category D) to enter Germany or another Schengen state.
8 For your future residency in Germany, you need to apply for a residence permit at the »» Ausländerbehörde (Immigration Office).
9 You can find the documents you require and the prerequisites here:
10 Reuniting family members with foreign citizens
11 Reuniting family members with German citizens
12 Foreigners who have a valid residence permit and only speak a little or no German can take part in the integration courses run by the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF).
13 In many cases, language knowledge is a condition for obtaining the right to settle in Germany (Niederlassungserlaubnis).
14 The Ausländerbehörde (Immigration Office) can oblige you to take part in an integration course if you cannot make yourself understood in German and are applying for a residence permit for the first time:
15 Find out more
16 People who receive a residence permit for family reunification are permitted to work.
17 The residence permit also serves as a work permit.
18 They are permitted to take up self-employed and employed work and have unrestricted access to the German labour market.
19 If the marital partnership has existed for at least three years, foreign spouses who join their spouses living in Germany are granted their own resident permit.
20 If the marriage/life partner or the children are threatened by violence from the other marriage/life partner and, therefore, it is not reasonable to expect them to stay in the marriage relationship, exceptions can be made.
21 In certain cases it is possible that an independent right of residence can be issued at an earlier stage.

16 can be taken into account.

0 Asylum seekers
1 During the asylum procedure, legal limitations mean that it is not possible to travel abroad.
2 Exceptions are made to allow school pupils to take part in class trips.
3 These must be clarified with the »» Ausländerbehörde (Immigration Office) at an early stage.
4 As the Aufenthaltsgestattung (temporary residence permit) is not a full residence permit and therefore not a travel document, there is no basis for re-entry into Germany unless permission to leave the country is obtained.
5 Foreign trips (with subsequent re-entry into Germany) are not possible.
6 Exceptions are made to allow school pupils to take part in class trips.
7 These must be clarified with the »» Ausländerbehörde (Immigration Office) at an early stage.
8 As the Duldung (temporary postponement of deportation) is not a full residence permit and ultimately is aimed at ending your residence, there is no basis for re-entry into Germany unless permission to leave the country is obtained.
9 If the asylum application is rejected, you will normally receive a request to leave the country with a threat of deportation.
10 The request to leave gives you a date by which you must leave Germany.
11 If the application is rejected as being “obviously without reason” or “invalid”, the deadline to leave is one week.
12 In this case, you can appeal to the courts against this decision and make an emergency application (Eilantrag).
13 To do this you should definitely get professional legal advice.
14 If the application is rejected as being “without reason”, the deadline to leave is 30 days.
15 In this case, you can appeal to the courts against this decision and make an emergency application (Eilantrag).
16 To do this you should definitely get professional legal advice.
17 If you decide on to depart voluntarily,
18 As you will have very little time after rejection of your application, you should get advice about this issue before your asylum procedure is decided and think about whether voluntary departure is possible for you.
19 A deportation is ending the stay of a person who is obliged to leave the country, even if they do not agree with this.
20 Before deportation occurs, the person will have received a request to leave (expulsion, permit refusal, departure decision ...) with a departure deadline.
21 If the departure deadline passes and you have not left the country, you can be deported.
22 The police are responsible for carrying out deportations.
23 Persons with an Aufenthaltsgestattung (temporary residence permit) or a Duldung (temporary postponement of deportation) who do not have any chances of a work permit or permission to undertake an apprenticeship or a job, can sometimes stay in Germany via the following route:
24 Please note:
25 for this route you need to fulfil many conditions.
26 Be sure to get advice in advance to be able to assess whether this route can work for you.
